indicators.justification:
Since 2017, French companies and entities mentioned in the article L. 561-45-1 of the Monetary and Financial Code have the legal obligation to declare beneficial ownership (1). To date, over 3.5 million companies and entities have filed the mandatory beneficial ownership declaration, available for free (2) on INPI website, which is timely updated (3). 
However only partial information is available to the public, and we cannot track historical data over time. The publication of this data doesn't follow any standards, and the data are only available in French. Only authorized entities identified by Ordinance No. 2020-115 of February 12, 2020 can access the full records, free of charge (4). The authorized entities can access the dataset in machine-readable format (5).
In France, the full availability of beneficial ownership data structure is legally enforced to protect owners' private information in order to comply with the French law No. 78-17 relating to computers, files and freedoms, January 6, 1978 (6).

indicators.justification:
The HATVP has a clear and accessible website, with a section dedicated to open data where all datasets and supporting documents are available to download (1). They also developed a user-friendly webpage to browse data online without downloading data (2). The HATVP actively promotes the reuse of those data by civil society, by participating to hackathons (3) and partnering with civic tech organisations (4) to improve data accessibility. 

The French framework distinguishes between "declarations of assets" and "declarations of interests". Available data mostly consist of declarations of interests. Declarations of assets are only published as open data for ministers.

When data is available, the datasets are well structured and easy to find and download. However, the data suffer from major loopholes, notably regarding for the report of side incomes, and are insufficiently updated. Those loopholes are documented in a report by Transparency International (5).

indicators.justification:
In theory, political finance data are covered by the "open data by default" principle, applicable to the French administration as a whole and explicitly incorporated in the Electoral Code: « the commission ensures the publication of campaign finance accounts in an open standard, easily reusable and machine-readable, and ensures their publication in the Official Journal. » (1) Therefore, the CNCCFP publishes a number of datasets on the national open data portal, mostly in CSV format (2). A platform to help visualizing data on political parties is available (3).

However, in practice, significant limits are observed.
First, data available often consists of relatively aggregated data, with not enough details. For campaign finance, supporting documents are not available as open data ; citizens need to make an appointment and go physically to the CNCCFP headquarters to get access to them (4) ; this right to information was obtained following a procedure filled by journalists against the CNCCFP in 2015 (5). Some data are available in PDF in the CNCCFP's annual reports but not published as open data simultaneously (6). 
For political parties, financial accounts must be reported in a standardized template ; for each financial category, some breakdown is available, although remaining very broad in many cases. For instance, for assets and liabilities, a balance sheet is provided but it does not contain data such as the list of real estate properties owned by the party ; significant amounts (sometimes exceeding 1MEUR) are often reported in vague and miscellaneous categories such as "other debts" or "other fixed assets". Details on political parties' spendings are reported and published with some breakdown by broad categories, but details is unavailable (even on site upon appointment) (4, ibid).

Second, datasets are usually published after long delays. The data related to the last European elections (2019) and municipal elections (2020) were not yet published when those lines are written (July 2021), despite the existence of articles in the news commenting the CNCCFP's decisions (7) ; the data contained in those articles could only be obtained by the journalists on site at the CNCCFP headquarters (4, ibid).

Details on donors are unavailable, be it for parties or campaigns, despite the fact that parties and candidates must transfer the list of their donors to the CNCCFP so that donations ceilings can be controlled. Journalists, when they make an appointment to the CNCCFP, only get access to anonymized data (8). When they get access to the data, it is usually via leaks, not open data (9).

Political parties : there is a section for in kind and non-financial support in the political parties datasets ("concours en nature" tab). In practice, this section is usually poorly reported by parties and candidates. Several upfront national political parties do not declare any in-kind and non-financial support.

Data on in-kind donations are poorly available, which is probably a consequence of the strong regulation on corporate donations (in-kind donations are prohibited, and therefore in-kind donations mostly consist of volunteering time by members, hard to trace to aggregate). There is a section dedicated to it in the political parties reporting template, but it is not or very poorly reported. For campaign finance, details are unavailable as open data, but some information can be obtained on site upon appointment (such as an equivalence in mileage costs of cars put at disposition for free by members or campaigners).

Finally, more than 20% of existing political parties are not compliant with their reporting requirements (10).

There is a serious lack of interoperability among datasets. Obstacles to interoperability include: the identities of politicians targeted by lobbyists are not reported ; the private companies mentioned in the asset declarations of public officials are not linked to the national register number ; some data such as addresses (be it in the asset declaration datasets or in the land datasets) are considered to be private data and are therefore not published ; identities of the donors is not published in political finance datasets. 

The IntegrityWatch platform, run by Transparency International France, tried to cross analyse datasets and reached the conclusion that it was hardly possible to do it automatically without heavy manual work (1). Policy recommendations include modifying the data to allow cross analysis, notably by using common identifiers for companies in the asset declarations, lobbying register and national company register.

Interoperability has been identified as a challenge to open data as a tool for public integrity since 2016. indicators.justification:
The framework assessed for generating and publishing open data in France is the French law n° 2016-1321 for a Digital Republic, October 7, 2016, (Loi Lemaire) (1). A national open data public platform enables French public services to publish data and civil society to add to it, with a view to the joint production of information of general interest (2). A French Chief Data Officer, reporting to the Prime Minister, was appointed by decree in October 2019, to coordinate the design and implementation of the State's strategy in the data domain (3). The service is managed by the ETALAB unit (4). 
The law which has full force doesn't provide a specific definition of "open data". The term "open data" (legally translated by "Données Ouvertes" in French) falls under the chapter 1 of the law: the circulation of data and knowledge. Notwithstanding, the CNIL, the French independent administrative authority (DPA) that controls data processing and freedoms, and the privacy of data, gives a full definition of "Open Data" (5).
The French framework has legal restrictions on open licensing (6). Those restrictions limit the use of open data that contain personal and private information, defined in the French law n° 78-17, relating to computers, files and freedoms, January 6, 1978 (7). Thus, the re-user must complete all necessary formalities with the CNIL.
No specific standards are required for publishing open data, the law n° 2016-1321 for a Digital Republic, October 7, 2016, mentions in the article L.300-4 that any provision made in electronic form in application of this law is made in an open standard, easily reusable and exploitable by an automated processing system. 
There is no training or capacity building among government officials, however the government launched a public-private initiative for open data within governmental agencies. Selected entrepreneurs for public good work with governmental officials to expand the publishing and the re-using (8).
The law applies to all French localities, government agencies and public administration, but the implementation is very slow (9)(10). In a summary published on March 11, 2019, the Court of Auditors recommends "more effective management of the opening of data" by the State (11). 
On April 27, 2021, the Prime Minister requested the appointment of data administrators in several ministries or pioneer administrations to accelerate the movement (12).

indicators.justification:
France has a relatively robust legal framework on political finance, with clear definitions of campaigning activities, clear rules on income and spendings allowed, and spending limits during campaigns. Those rules are mostly incorporated in the Electoral Code for campaign finance and in the Law n°88-227 of March 11 1988 (1), which is regularly updated (last substantial reform in september 2017). This is complemented by official guidelines published by the National Commission for Campaign Finance and Political Finance (CNCCFP) summarizing hard law and case law (2). Candidates and parties must comply with the same accounting guidelines, set by a National Accounting Authority (3). According to the Code Electoral, « the commission ensures the publication of campaign finance accounts in an open standard, easily reusable and machine-readable, and ensures their publication in the Official Journal. » (4)

In general, rules are stronger for campaign finance (all invoices must be reported to the CNCCFP, etc.) than for party finance (data only reported as summary) ; this can be explained by article 4 of the Constitution, which states that political parties "carry out their activities freely" (5).

Despite this relatively strong processes on the paper, major scandals have occurred in the last decades, notably about the presidential elections (6) and illicit loans from foreign organisations (7). Therefore, civil society is actively calling for reforms to address loopholes (8).

In many cases, it is necessary to make a physical appointment and go on site to get access to some data, notably for supporting documents that are never available online.

indicators.justification:
A National Commission for Access to Administrative Document (CADA) was established in 1978. This independent agency is responsible for ensuring the proper implementation of RTI laws and procedures ; it processes complaints from citizens against public authorities when their first level requests failed, and issues pre-litigation opinions (« avis ») (1). This commission is required by law to regularly publish the list of all favorable opinions issued by the commission. This list specifies which administration is targeted, the reference of the administrative document requested, the reaction - if any - of the administration to this decision, as well as, when applicable, details on litigation (2). 

All legally required data have to be published by the CADA as open data (3). 

In addition, it should be noted that some data are collected and/or published by the commission in practice, although this is not explicitly required by law (hence some negative answers in this survey even when data is collected and available). This is notably the case for data regarding how long it took the relevant government agency or agencies to fill requests, data regarding material withheld and the reasons for withholding it, and on the fact that information is linked to the relevant agency, department, or other governmental entity. In practice, the CADA publishes in its annual report (pdf - not open data) annual statistics on the number of requests received and processed (4) - although not explicitly required by law. More generally, the legal requirements targets favorable opinions only (3 - ibid), but the CADA publishes data for all kind of opinions (favorable and rejections) in practice.

A specific comment should be made on data regarding appeals to RTI determinations and their results. Those data are required by law to be collected and published in theory, according to article 342-3 of the Code of Relations between Citizens and the Administration (3, ibid). However, in practice, the broader regulatory context does not provide the CADA with the adequate means to follow up those appeals exhaustively for two reasons. First, the requesting citizens do not necessarly inform the CADA about appeals, because appeal against first-level administrations (the CADA issues mandatory pre-litigation « opinions » that are not considered as administrative decisions subject to appeal). Second, there is no open data of legal decisions (reform is planned but was not yet implemented at the time of this survey) (5). In practice, the CADA watches closely all legal decisions and they are commented extensively in the CADA's annual reports (not in open data) (6).
 
Although the answers in this survey focus primarily on the CADA, it is worth mentioning that, for first-level requests (requests sent by citizens to a given authority before the CADA is seized) are theoretically covered by the "open data by default" overarching principle (established by the "Law for a Digital Republic" passed in 2016, and applicable to all public agencies in all fields). (7) This principle could cover (at least in theory) data on RTI performance held by most public authorities but, to our knowledge, there isn't any example of a municipality or public agency publishing aggregated data on RTI performance (8).

Open Procurement Data is used by the government to feed into the three-yearly report to be submitted to the European Commission on the monitoring of public procurement, and to comply with its adhesion to Contracting 5, a group of governments to foster openness, innovation, integrity and better business and civic engagement in government contracting and procurement (4).

There's no evidence of civil society and private sector making use of the data, although the objectives are intended for them, as explained by the manager of data collection at ETALAB (5). Some stakeholders advocate for the use of AI to improve analytics, decision-making, access to small companies, and fairness (6)(7).
